trans-unit.source: How to migrate from a RemoteApp VNET to an Azure VNET
trans-unit.target: How to migrate from a RemoteApp VNET to an Azure VNET

trans-unit.source: Learn how to migrate from a RemoteApp VNET to an Azure VNET
trans-unit.target: Learn how to migrate from a RemoteApp VNET to an Azure VNET

trans-unit.source: Good news!
trans-unit.target: Good news!

trans-unit.source: We have enabled you to deploy hybrid RemoteApp collections directly into your existing Azure virtual networks (VNETs) instead of creating RemoteApp-specific VNETs.
trans-unit.target: We have enabled you to deploy hybrid RemoteApp collections directly into your existing Azure virtual networks (VNETs) instead of creating RemoteApp-specific VNETs.

trans-unit.source: This lets you take advantage of the latest VNET features (like ExpressRoute) and give your hybrid collections direct network access to other Azure services and virtual machines deployed to that VNET.
trans-unit.target: This lets you take advantage of the latest VNET features (like ExpressRoute) and give your hybrid collections direct network access to other Azure services and virtual machines deployed to that VNET.

trans-unit.source: (This gets you better performance and easier setup than VNET-to-VNET configurations).
trans-unit.target: (This gets you better performance and easier setup than VNET-to-VNET configurations).

trans-unit.source: Let’s say that you’ve already created a hybrid RemoteApp collection called OriginalCollection with a RemoteApp VNET called RemoteAppVNET.
trans-unit.target: Let’s say that you’ve already created a hybrid RemoteApp collection called OriginalCollection with a RemoteApp VNET called RemoteAppVNET.

trans-unit.source: Here are the steps to migrate it to a new Azure VNET called AzureVNET.
trans-unit.target: Here are the steps to migrate it to a new Azure VNET called AzureVNET.

trans-unit.source: On the Networks tab in the management portal, create a VNET called AzureVNET, using the same location, DNS configuration, and address space (for at least one of the AzureVNET subnets) as you used for RemoteAppVNET.
trans-unit.target: On the Networks tab in the management portal, create a VNET called AzureVNET, using the same location, DNS configuration, and address space (for at least one of the AzureVNET subnets) as you used for RemoteAppVNET.

trans-unit.source: Configure AzureVNET to either host or have network connectivity to the Active Directory deployment that OriginalCollection is domain joined to.
trans-unit.target: Configure AzureVNET to either host or have network connectivity to the Active Directory deployment that OriginalCollection is domain joined to.

trans-unit.source: On the RemoteApps tab, create a new RemoteApp collection called New Collection.
trans-unit.target: On the RemoteApps tab, create a new RemoteApp collection called New Collection.

trans-unit.source: (Use the Create with VNET option, not Quick Create.)
trans-unit.target: (Use the Create with VNET option, not Quick Create.)

trans-unit.source: Configure NewCollection to be deployed to a subnet in AzureVNET.
trans-unit.target: Configure NewCollection to be deployed to a subnet in AzureVNET.

trans-unit.source: Configure NewCollection to use the same image and domain join information as you used for OriginalCollection.
trans-unit.target: Configure NewCollection to use the same image and domain join information as you used for OriginalCollection.

trans-unit.source: After a few hours, NewCollection will show up in your collection list with an Active state.
trans-unit.target: After a few hours, NewCollection will show up in your collection list with an Active state.

trans-unit.source: Now, if you DON’T need to migrate any user information from the original collection to the new collection, do these steps next:
trans-unit.target: Now, if you DON’T need to migrate any user information from the original collection to the new collection, do these steps next:

trans-unit.source: Delete OriginalCollection.
trans-unit.target: Delete OriginalCollection.

trans-unit.source: Delete RemoteAppVNET.
trans-unit.target: Delete RemoteAppVNET.

trans-unit.source: And, you’re done!
trans-unit.target: And, you’re done!

trans-unit.source: Alternately, if you DO need to migrate user information from the original collection to the new collection, do these steps next:
trans-unit.target: Alternately, if you DO need to migrate user information from the original collection to the new collection, do these steps next:

trans-unit.source: Send an email to <linkText>remoteappforum@microsoft.com</linkText><title></title> with your Azure subscription ID, the name of your original collection, and the name of your new collection, and ask them to migrate your user information.
trans-unit.target: Send an email to <linkText>remoteappforum@microsoft.com</linkText><title></title> with your Azure subscription ID, the name of your original collection, and the name of your new collection, and ask them to migrate your user information.

trans-unit.source: Within 2 business days the RemoteApp team will move the user access list and all user documents and user settings from the original collection to the new collection.
trans-unit.target: Within 2 business days the RemoteApp team will move the user access list and all user documents and user settings from the original collection to the new collection.

trans-unit.source: Delete OriginalCollection.
trans-unit.target: Delete OriginalCollection.

trans-unit.source: Delete RemoteAppVNET.
trans-unit.target: Delete RemoteAppVNET.

trans-unit.source: And now, you’re done!
trans-unit.target: And now, you’re done!

trans-unit.source: If you have any questions or need special assistance, please email <linkText>remoteappforum@microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you have any questions or need special assistance, please email <linkText>remoteappforum@microsoft.com</linkText><title></title>.
